  "article_text": [
    "a central concern in optimization is to understand @xmath0 , the convex hull of the set of feasible solutions @xmath1 , to a given problem . in many instances ,",
    "the set of feasible solutions to an optimization problem is the set of real solutions to a polynomial system : @xmath2 , where @xmath3 : = \\rr[x_1,\\ldots , x_n]$ ] .",
    "this set is the _ real variety _ , @xmath4 , of the _ ideal _ @xmath5 in @xmath6",
    "$ ] generated by @xmath7 , and it is often necessary to compute or represent @xmath8 exactly or at least approximately .",
    "recall that @xmath9 , the closure of @xmath8 , is cut out by the inequalities @xmath10 as @xmath11 runs over all linear polynomials that are non - negative on @xmath12 .",
    "( call @xmath13 $ ] a _ linear _ polynomial if it is affine linear of the form @xmath14 . ) a classical certificate for the non - negativity of a polynomial @xmath11 on @xmath4 is the existence of a _ sum of squares _ ( _ sos _ )",
    "polynomial @xmath15 that is congruent to @xmath11 mod @xmath5 ( i.e. , @xmath16 ) , written as @xmath17 mod @xmath5 .",
    "if this is the case , we say that @xmath11 _ is sos mod _ @xmath5 .",
    "hence a natural relaxation of @xmath9 is the closed convex set : @xmath18 depending on @xmath5 , ( [ eqn : sos relaxation ] ) may be strictly larger than @xmath9 since there may be polynomials that are non - negative on @xmath4 but not sos mod @xmath5 .",
    "however , in many interesting cases , ( [ eqn : sos relaxation ] ) will equal @xmath9 . by bounding the degree of the @xmath19 s that appear in the sos representations , and gradually increasing this bound",
    ", we obtain a hierarchy of relaxations to @xmath9 . in @xcite , lovsz asked a question that leads to the study of this hierarchy .",
    "to explain it , we first introduce some definitions .     "the polynomial @xmath11 is * @xmath21-sos * mod @xmath5 if there exists @xmath22_k$ ] for some @xmath23 such that @xmath24 .",
    "the ideal @xmath5 is * @xmath21-sos * if _ every _ polynomial that is non - negative on @xmath4 is @xmath21-sos mod @xmath5 .",
    "if every polynomial of degree at most @xmath25 that is non - negative on @xmath12 is @xmath21-sos mod @xmath5 , we say that @xmath5 is * @xmath26-sos*.    [ ex : runningex ] consider the principal ideal @xmath27 $ ] .",
    "then @xmath28 , and any linear polynomial that is non - negative over @xmath12 is of the form @xmath29 , where @xmath30 .",
    "since @xmath31 mod @xmath5 , @xmath5 is @xmath32-sos . check that @xmath33 is not @xmath34-sos mod @xmath5 and so",
    ", @xmath5 is not @xmath35-sos .    in @xcite",
    ", lovsz asked the following question .",

    "how about @xmath36-sos ?    the geometry behind the above algebraic question leads to a natural hierarchy of relaxations of @xmath37 which we now introduce .",
    "the name comes from earlier work of lovsz and will be explained in section  [ sec : examples ] .",

    "as seen in example  [ ex : runningex ] , @xmath37 may not be closed while the theta bodies are .",
    "therefore , the theta - body sequence of @xmath5 can converge , if at all , only to @xmath44 .",
    "a natural question at this point is whether the algebraic notion of an ideal being @xmath36-sos is equivalent to the geometric notion of being @xmath40-exact .",
    "[ lem:1ksos implies thetakexact ] if an ideal @xmath45 $ ] is @xmath36-sos then it is @xmath40-exact .",
    "let @xmath5 be @xmath36-sos and @xmath46 be not in @xmath47 . by the _ separation theorem _ ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem iii.1.3 ) there exists a linear polynomial @xmath11 , non - negative over @xmath47 , such that @xmath48 .",
    "however , since @xmath5 is @xmath36-sos , @xmath11 is @xmath21-sos mod @xmath5 and so @xmath49 .",
    "hence @xmath50 and so , @xmath41 equals @xmath47 .",
    "interestingly , the converse of lemma  [ lem:1ksos implies thetakexact ] is false in general .",
    "[ ex : conversefalse ] consider @xmath51 $ ] with @xmath52 .",
    "all linear polynomials that are non - negative on @xmath4 are of the form @xmath53 for some @xmath54 . if @xmath55 , then @xmath56 mod @xmath5 .",

    "we will prove in section  [ sec : theta bodies ] that the converse of lemma  [ lem:1ksos implies thetakexact ] holds for real radical ideals .",
    "these ideals occur frequently in applications and for them , problem  [ prob : lovasz ] is asking when @xmath5 is @xmath58-exact , or more generally , @xmath40-exact .    *",
    "contents of this paper . *",
    "recall that a _ semidefinite program _ ( sdp ) is an optimization problem in the space of real symmetric matrices of the form : @xmath70 where @xmath71 and the @xmath72 s are real symmetric matrices .",
    "the notation @xmath73 implies that @xmath74 is _ positive semidefinite_. sdps generalize linear programs and can be solved efficiently @xcite . in section  [ sec : theta bodies ] we prove that under a certain technical hypothesis ( satisfied by real radical ideals for instance ) , the theta body sequence of an ideal @xmath5 is a modified version of a hierarchy of relaxations for the convex hull of a basic semialgebraic set , due to lasserre @xcite . in this case , each theta body is the closure of the projection of a _ spectrahedron _ ( feasible region of a sdp ) , and an explicit representation is possible using the _",
    "combinatorial moment matrices _ introduced by laurent @xcite .",
    "when @xmath5 is a real radical ideal , we further prove that @xmath5 is @xmath36-sos if and only if @xmath5 is @xmath40-exact which impacts later sections .    in section  [ sec",
    ": examples ] we illustrate the theta body sequence for the maximum stable set and maximum cut problems in a graph which are two very well - studied problems from combinatorial optimization . the stable set problem motivated problem  [ prob : lovasz ] .",
    "we explain this connection in detail in section  [ sec : examples ] .    in section  [ sec :",
    "structure ] we solve problem  [ prob : lovasz ] for vanishing ideals of finite point sets in @xmath75 .",
    "this situation arises often in applications and is the typical set up in combinatorial optimization .",
    "several corollaries follow : if @xmath76 is finite and its vanishing ideal @xmath77 is @xmath35-sos then @xmath1 is affinely equivalent to a subset of @xmath78 and its convex hull can have at most @xmath79 facets .",
    "if @xmath1 is the vertex set of a down - closed @xmath80-polytope in @xmath75 , then @xmath77 is @xmath35-sos if and only if @xmath81 is the stable set polytope of a perfect graph .",
    "families of finite sets in growing dimension with @xmath35-sos vanishing ideals are exhibited .    in section  [ sec : structure arbitrary s ] , we give an intrinsic description of the first theta body , @xmath82 , of an arbitrary polynomial ideal @xmath5 in terms of the convex quadrics in @xmath5 .",
    "this leads to non - trivial examples of @xmath58-exact ideals with arbitrarily high - dimensional real varieties and reveals the algebraic - geometric structure of @xmath82 .",
    "analogous descriptions for higher theta bodies remain open .    in @xcite",
    ", lasserre introduced the _ schmdgen bounded degree representation _ ( s - bdr ) and the _ putinar - prestel bounded degree representation _ ( pp - bdr ) properties of a compact basic semialgebraic set @xmath83 ( where @xmath84 $ ] ) , defined as follows :    * @xmath85 has the s - bdr property if there exists a positive integer @xmath21 such that _ almost all _ linear @xmath11 that are positive over @xmath85 has a representation as @xmath86 } \\sigma_j g_j$ ] where @xmath87 are sos , @xmath88 and the degree of @xmath89 is at most @xmath90 for all @xmath91 : =    \\{1,\\ldots , m\\}$ ] . * @xmath85 has the pp - bdr property if there exists a positive integer @xmath21 such that _ almost all _ linear @xmath11 that are positive over @xmath85 has a representation as @xmath92 where @xmath93 are sos , @xmath94 and the degree of @xmath95 is at most @xmath90 for @xmath96 .",
    "call the smallest such @xmath21 the s - bdr ( respectively , pp - bdr ) rank of @xmath85 . here",
    "`` almost all '' means all except a set of lebesgue measure zero .",
    "note that the pp - bdr property implies that s - bdr property .",
    "for an ideal @xmath97 $ ] , @xmath98 is the , possibly non - compact , basic semialgebraic set @xmath99 .",
    "when @xmath4 is compact , its pp - bdr property is closely related to the @xmath36-sos and @xmath40-exact properties of @xmath5 .",
    "however , these notions are not exactly comparable since the pp - bdr rank of @xmath4 depends on the choice of generators of @xmath5 , and only the linear polynomials that are positive ( as opposed to non - negative ) over @xmath4 . regardless ,",
    "note that if @xmath12 has pp - bdr rank @xmath21 , then @xmath5 has theta - rank at most @xmath21 .    * acknowledgments*. we thank monique laurent and ting kei pong for several useful inputs to this paper .",
    "we also thank the referees for their many constructive comments that helped the organization of the paper .",
    "in definition  [ def : theta ] we introduced the @xmath21-th theta body of a polynomial ideal @xmath38 $ ] and observed that these bodies create a nested sequence of closed convex relaxations of @xmath37 with @xmath100 .",
    "lasserre @xcite and parrilo @xcite have independently introduced hierarchies of semidefinite relaxations for polynomial optimization over basic semialgebraic sets in @xmath75 using results from real algebraic geometry and the theory of moments .",
    "we first examine the connection between the theta bodies of an ideal @xmath5 and lasserre s relaxations for @xmath37 .",

    "the original lasserre relaxations in @xcite approximate @xmath0 for a basic semialgebraic set @xmath131 by the sets @xmath132 ' , \\,\\ , y(1 ) = 1 , \\,\\ ,    y\\left(\\sum_{i=0}^{m } s_ig_i \\right ) \\geq 0 \\right \\}\\ ] ] where @xmath133 are sos , @xmath94 and the degree of @xmath134 is bounded above by some fixed positive integer . when there are equations among the @xmath135 , both lasserre @xcite ( for @xmath80 point sets ) and laurent @xcite ( more generally for finite varieties ) propose doing computations mod the ideal generated by the polynomials defining the equations , to increase efficiency .",

    "we close with a brief discussion of ideals for which the theta body sequence is guaranteed to converge ( finitely or asymptotically ) to @xmath231 .    1 .",
    "if @xmath12 is finite the results in @xcite imply that @xmath5 is @xmath40-exact for some finite @xmath21 .",
    "if @xmath232 is finite ( @xmath5 is zero - dimensional ) , then @xmath21 can be bounded above by the maximum degree of a linear basis of @xmath6/i$ ] @xcite ( see section  [ subsec : combinatorial matrices ] ) . however , as in @xmath233 , we can not guarantee that @xmath5 is @xmath36-sos for any @xmath21 , even when @xmath5 is zero - dimensional . if @xmath5 is zero - dimensional and radical , then in fact",
    ", @xmath5 is @xmath36-sos for finite @xmath21 with @xmath234 ( see @xcite , ( * ? ? ? * theorem 2.4 ) ) .",
    "better bounds are often possible as in remark  [ rem : k parallel translates ] . for an ideal @xmath137",
    "$ ] we summarize the above results in the following table .",
    "+ @xmath235 \\ar[d]^{\\tiny{i = \\sqrt{i } } }   & { { \\mathcal v}}_\\rr(i ) \\,\\,\\text{finite } \\ar[d ] \\\\",

    "if @xmath12 is not finite but is compact , schmdgen s positivstellensatz ( * ? ?",
    "* chapter 3 ) implies that the theta body sequence of @xmath5 converges ( at least asymptotically ) to @xmath236 ( i.e. , @xmath237 ) .",
    "if @xmath12 is not compact , then the study of the theta body hierarchy becomes harder .",
    "scheiderer ( * ? ? ?",
    "* chapter 2 ) has identified ideals @xmath5 with @xmath12 not necessarily compact , but of dimension at most two , for which every @xmath238 mod @xmath5 is sos mod @xmath5 . in all these cases , the theta body sequence of @xmath5 converges to @xmath236 .",
    "the results of schmdgen and scheiderer mentioned above fit within a general framework in real algebraic geometry that is concerned with when an arbitrary @xmath13 $ ] that is positive or non - negative over a basic semi - algebraic set is sos modulo certain algebraic objects defined by the set .",
    "we only care about real varieties and whether linear polynomials that are non - negative over them are sos mod their ideals .",
    "therefore , often there are ideals @xmath5 that are @xmath40-exact or @xmath36-sos for which there are non - linear polynomials @xmath11 such that @xmath238 mod @xmath5 but @xmath11 is not sos mod @xmath5 .",
    "for instance , the proof of theorem  [ thm : intersection ] will show that @xmath239 is @xmath35-sos for all @xmath240 , but a result of scheiderer ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 2.6.3 ) implies that when @xmath241 , there is always some non - linear @xmath11 non - negative on @xmath242 that is not sos mod @xmath243 .      to compute theta bodies",
    "we must work with the truncated quadratic module @xmath104 which requires computing sums of squares in @xmath6/i$ ] as described in @xcite , or dually , using the combinatorial moment matrices introduced by laurent in @xcite .",
    "we describe the latter viewpoint here as it is more natural for theta bodies .",
    "consider a basis @xmath244 for @xmath6/i$ ] , and define @xmath245 .",
    "for a positive integer @xmath21 , let @xmath246 , and set @xmath247 .",
    "we may assume that the elements of @xmath248 are indexed in order of increasing degree .",
    "let @xmath249 be the vector of coordinates of @xmath203 with respect to @xmath248 .",
    "note that @xmath250 has only finitely many non - zero coordinates .",
    "let @xmath251 .",
    "then the * combinatorial moment matrix * @xmath252 is the ( possibly infinite ) matrix indexed by @xmath253 whose @xmath254 entry is @xmath255 the * @xmath21-th - truncated combinatorial moment matrix * @xmath256 is the finite ( upper left principal ) submatrix of @xmath257 indexed by @xmath258 .",
    "although only a finite number of the components in @xmath259 are non - zero , for practical purposes we need to control exactly which indices can be non - zero .",
    "one way to do this is by choosing @xmath248 such that if @xmath260 has degree @xmath21 then @xmath261 .",
    "this is true for instance if @xmath248 is the set of _ standard monomials _ of a _ term order _ that respects degree @xcite .",
    "if @xmath248 has this property then @xmath256 only depends on the entries of @xmath262 indexed by @xmath263 .",
    "[ thm : combinatorial matrices formulation ] for each positive integer @xmath21 , @xmath264 where @xmath265 is the first entry of @xmath266 , @xmath267 is the projection onto the coordinates indexed by @xmath268 , and for @xmath269 , @xmath270",
    ".    we may identify @xmath271 with the operator @xmath272/i)'$ ] where @xmath273 if @xmath274 and zero otherwise .",
    "then @xmath256 is simply the matrix representation of @xmath275 in the basis @xmath248 , since we assumed that if @xmath276 then @xmath277 depends only on the value of @xmath278 on @xmath263 .",
    "therefore , @xmath279 equals @xmath280/i ) ' ,    h_{\\bar{y},k } \\succeq 0\\}.\\ ] ] furthermore , since @xmath281 is linear whenever @xmath282 , @xmath283 so by lemma  [ thm : sdpformulation ] , @xmath284 .",
    "[ cor : simple version ] suppose @xmath285 and denote by @xmath286 the first @xmath287 coordinates of @xmath288 , then @xmath289    by corollary [ cor : simple version ] , optimizing a linear function over @xmath144 , hence over @xmath290 , is an sdp and can be solved efficiently .",
    "[ ex : runningex2 ] consider the ideal @xmath291 $ ] from example  [ ex : runningex ] for which @xmath292 was not closed but @xmath5 was @xmath293-exact and @xmath32-sos .",

    "we now show that in the particular case of vanishing ideals of @xmath80 points , which are real radical ideals , the closure in theorem  [ thm : basis free formulation ] ( @xmath316 ) is not needed .",
    "most ideals that occur in combinatorial optimization have this form and we will see important examples in section  [ sec : examples ] .",
    "remark [ rem : running example ] shows that the closure can not be removed for arbitrary finite point sets .",
    "[ prop : theta = q ] if @xmath1 is a set of @xmath80 points in @xmath75 and @xmath317 then for all positive integers @xmath21 , @xmath318 .    by corollary  [ cor : theta - lasserre ]",

    "@xmath332 is positive ( ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 7.7.6 ) ) .",
    "an important area of application for the theta body hierarchy constructed in section  [ sec : theta bodies ] is _ combinatorial optimization _ which is typically concerned with optimizing a linear function over a finite set of integer points . in this section ,",
    "we compute theta bodies for two important problems in combinatorial optimization ",
    "the _ maximum stable set problem _ and the _ maximum cut problem _ in a graph .",
    "we explain the observations about the stable set problem which motivated lovsz to pose problem  [ prob : lovasz ] .",
    "the cut problem is modeled in two different ways .",
    "the first is a non - standard approach which is described fully .",
    "for the second , more standard model of the cut problem , theta bodies provide a new hierarchy of semidefinite relaxations for the _ cut polytope _ that is studied in detail in @xcite .",
    "we outline those results briefly here .",
    "a recent trend in theoretical computer science has been to study the computational complexity of approximating problems in combinatorial optimization via the standard hierarchies of convex relaxations to these problems such as those in @xcite and @xcite .",
    "our theta body approach provides a new mechanism to establish such complexity results .",
    "let @xmath333,e)$ ] be an undirected graph with vertex set @xmath334=\\{1,\\ldots , n\\}$ ] and edge set @xmath335 .",
    "stable set _ in @xmath336 is a set @xmath337 $ ] such that for all @xmath338 , @xmath339 .",
    "the maximum stable set problem seeks the stable set of largest cardinality in @xmath336 , the size of which is the _ stability number _ of @xmath336 , denoted as @xmath340 .",
    "the maximum stable set problem can be modeled as follows . for each stable",
    "set @xmath337 $ ] , let @xmath341 be its _ characteristic vector _ defined as @xmath342 if @xmath343 and @xmath344 otherwise .",
    "let @xmath345 be the set of characteristic vectors of all stable sets in @xmath336 .",
    "then @xmath346 is called the _ stable set polytope _ of @xmath336 and the maximum stable set problem is , in theory , the linear program @xmath347 with optimal value @xmath340 .",
    "however , @xmath348 is not known apriori , and so one resorts to relaxations of it over which one can optimize @xmath349 .    in @xcite ,",
    "lovsz introduced , @xmath350 , a convex relaxation of @xmath348 , called the _ theta body _ of @xmath336 . the problem @xmath351 is a sdp which can be solved to arbitrary precision in polynomial time in the size of @xmath336 .",
    "the optimal value of this sdp is called the _ theta number _ of @xmath336 and provides an upper bound on @xmath340 .",
    "see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* chapter 9 ) and @xcite for more on the stable set problem and @xmath350 .",
    "the body @xmath350 was the first example of a sdp relaxation of a discrete optimization problem and snowballed the use of sdp in combinatorial optimization .",
    "see @xcite for surveys . recall that a graph @xmath336 is _ perfect _ if and only if @xmath336 has no induced odd cycles of length at least five or their complements .",
    "lovsz showed that @xmath352 if and only if @xmath336 is perfect .",
    "this equality shows that the maximum stable set problem can be solved in polynomial time in the size of @xmath336 when @xmath336 is a perfect graph , and this geometric proof is the only one known for this complexity result .",
    "the theta body @xmath350 has many definitions ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* chapter 9 ) ) but the one relevant for this paper was observed by lovsz and appears without proof in @xcite .",
    "let @xmath353 , \\,\\,\\ , x_ix_j \\,\\ , \\forall \\,\\ , \\{i , j\\ } \\in e \\rangle \\subseteq \\rr[\\xx]$ ] . then check that @xmath354 and that @xmath355 is both zero - dimensional and real radical .",
    "lovsz observed that @xmath356 by definition  [ def : theta ] ( 1 ) , @xmath350 is exactly the first theta body , @xmath357 , of the ideal @xmath355 , and by the above discussion , @xmath355 is @xmath58-exact ( i.e. , @xmath358 ) if and only if @xmath336 is perfect .",
    "lovsz observed that , in fact , @xmath355 is @xmath35-sos if and only if @xmath336 is perfect which motivated problem  [ prob : lovasz ] that asks for a characterizations of all @xmath35-sos ideals in @xmath6 $ ] .",
    "lovsz refers to a @xmath35-sos ideal as a _",
    "perfect ideal_. a @xmath35-sos ideal @xmath5 would have the property that its first and simplest theta body , @xmath82 , coincides with @xmath44 which is a valuable property for linear optimization over @xmath359 , especially when @xmath82 is computationally tractable .",
    "the theta body hierarchy of the ideal @xmath355 therefore naturally extends the theta body of @xmath336 to a family of nested relaxations of @xmath348 .",
    "further , the connection between @xmath350 and sums of squares polynomials motivated definition  [ def : theta ] which extends the construction of @xmath350 to a hierarchy of relaxations of @xmath4 for any ideal @xmath38 $ ] .",
    "we now explicity describe the @xmath21-th theta body of @xmath355 in terms of combinatorial moment matrices .    for",

    "the usual lasserre relaxations of the maximum stable set problem are set up from the following initial linear programming relaxation of @xmath348 : @xmath371 , \\ , 1-x_i - x_j \\geq 0 \\,\\,\\forall \\,\\,\\{i , j\\ } \\in e \\}.\\ ] ] note that @xmath372 .",
    "the @xmath21-th lasserre relaxation of @xmath348 ( see @xcite , @xcite ) uses both the ideal @xmath373 \\rangle$ ] and the inequality system describing @xmath374 , whereas in the theta body formulation , @xmath375 , there is only the ideal @xmath355 and no inequalities . despite this difference , ( * ? ? ?",
    "* lemma 20 ) proves that the usual lasserre hierarchy is exactly our theta body hierarchy for the stable set problem .",
    "this interpretation of the lasserre hierarchy provides new tools to understand these relaxations such as establishing the validity of inequalities over them as shown below .",
    "since no monomial in the basis @xmath248 of @xmath6/i_g$ ] has degree larger than @xmath340 , for any @xmath336 , @xmath355 is @xmath376-sos and @xmath377 .",

    "an induced odd cycle @xmath400 in @xmath336 , yields the well - known _ odd cycle inequality _",
    "@xmath401 that is satisfied by @xmath395 ( * ? ? ?",
    "* chapter 9 ) .",
    "proposition  [ prop:2sos ] implies that for any graph @xmath336 , @xmath402 satisfies all odd cycle inequalities from @xmath336 since every stable set @xmath403 in @xmath336 restricts to a stable set in an induced odd cycle in @xmath336 .",
    "this general result can also be proved using results from @xcite and @xcite .",
    "the direct arguments used in the proof of proposition  [ prop:2sos ] are examples of the algebraic _ inference rules _ outlined by lovsz in @xcite .",
    "similarly , one can also show that other well - known classes of inequalities such as the _ odd antihole _ and _ odd wheel _ inequalities ( * ? ? ?",
    "* chapter 9 ) are also valid for @xmath402 .",
    "schoenebeck @xcite has recently shown that there is no constant @xmath21 such that @xmath404 for all graphs @xmath336 ( as expected , unless p = np ) .",
    "however , no explicit family of graphs that exhibit this behaviour is known .",
    "given an undirected connected graph @xmath405 , e)$ ] and a partition of its vertex set @xmath334 $ ] into two parts @xmath406 and @xmath407 , the set of edges @xmath408 such that exactly one of @xmath409 or @xmath410 is in @xmath406 and the other in @xmath407 is the _ cut _ in @xmath336 induced by the partition @xmath411 .",
    "the cuts in @xmath336 are in bijection with the @xmath412 distinct partitions of @xmath334 $ ] into two sets .",
    "the maximum cut problem in @xmath336 seeks the cut in @xmath336 of largest cardinality .",
    "this problem is np - hard and has received a great deal of attention in the literature .",
    "a celebrated result in this area is an approximation algorithm for the max cut problem , due to goemans and williamson @xcite , that guarantees a cut of size at least @xmath413 of the optimal cut .",
    "it relies on a simple sdp relaxation of the problem .",
    "we first study a non - standard model of the max cut problem .",
    "let @xmath414 then the _ weighted _ max cut problem with non - negative weights @xmath415 on the edges @xmath416 is @xmath417 , and the vanishing ideal @xmath418 a basis of @xmath6/{\\i(sg)}$ ] is @xmath419 and @xmath420 lie in @xmath248 .",
    "therefore , @xmath421    in particular , @xmath422    note that for any graph @xmath336 , @xmath423 is the unit cube in @xmath424 which may not be equal to @xmath425 .",
    "this stands in contrast to the case of stable sets for which @xmath357 is a polytope if and only if @xmath426 .",
    "the ideal @xmath427 is @xmath58-exact if and only if @xmath336 is a bipartite graph .",
    "this follows immediately from the description of @xmath423 and from the fact that @xmath336 is bipartite if and only if it has no odd cycles .",
    "since the maximum degree of a monomial in @xmath248 is the size of the max cut in @xmath336 , the theta - rank of @xmath427 is bounded from above by the size of the max cut in @xmath336 .    [",
    "prop : increasingk ] there is no constant @xmath21 such that @xmath427 is @xmath40-exact for all graphs @xmath336 .",

    "we remark that the stable set problem and the first formulation of the max cut problem discussed above are special cases of the following general setup .",

    "let @xmath479 be a facet of @xmath81 , and @xmath480 its defining inequality in the given description of @xmath81 .",
    "then @xmath481 is @xmath34-sos mod @xmath77 if and only if there are linear polynomials @xmath482 $ ] such that @xmath483 . in particular , since @xmath484 on the vertices of @xmath479 , and all the @xmath485 are non - negative , each @xmath486 must be zero on all the vertices of @xmath479 .",

    "we derive various consequences of theorem  [ thm : perfect ] .",
    "finite point sets with property ( 5 ) in theorem  [ thm : perfect ] have been studied in various contexts . in particular , corollaries [ cor : perfect ] , [ cor : perfectgraph ] and [ cor : down - closed perfect ] below were also observed independently by greg kuperberg , raman sanyal , axel werner and gnter ziegler ( personal communication ) . in their work ,",
    "@xmath81 is called a * 2-level polytope * when property ( 5 ) in theorem  [ thm : perfect ] holds .",
    "if @xmath1 is a finite subset of @xmath505 and @xmath506 is the smallest lattice in @xmath505 containing @xmath1 , then the lattice polytope @xmath81 is said to be * compressed * if every _",
    "reverse lexicographic _ triangulation of the lattice points in @xmath81 is _ unimodular _ with respect to @xmath506 .",
    "compressed polytopes were introduced by stanley @xcite .",
    "corollary  [ cor : perfect ] ( 4 ) and theorem 2.4 in @xcite ( see also the references after theorem 2.4 in @xcite for earlier citations of part or unpublished versions of this result ) , imply that a finite set @xmath469 is exact if and only if @xmath81 is affinely equivalent to a compressed polytope .",
    "[ cor : perfect ] let @xmath507 be exact sets",
    ". then    1 .",
    "all points of @xmath1 are vertices of @xmath81 , 2 .",
    "the set of vertices of any face of @xmath81 is again exact , 3 .",
    "the product @xmath508 is exact , and 4 .",
    "@xmath81 is affinely equivalent to a @xmath80 polytope .",
    "the first three properties follow from theorem  [ thm : perfect ] ( 5 ) .",
    "if the dimension of @xmath81 is @xmath509 , then @xmath81 has at least @xmath25 non - parallel facets .",
    "if @xmath510 cuts out a facet in this collection , then @xmath81 is supported by both @xmath511 and a parallel translate of it .",
    "taking these two parallel hyperplanes from each of the @xmath25 facets gives a parallelepiped . by theorem  [ thm :",
    "perfect ] , @xmath1 is contained in the vertices of this parallelepiped intersected with the affine hull of @xmath1 .",
    "this proves ( 4 ) .    by corollary  [ cor : perfect ]",
    "( 4 ) , it essentially suffices to look at subsets of @xmath78 to obtain all exact finite varieties in @xmath75 . in @xmath512 , the set of vertices of any @xmath80-polytope",
    "verify this property .",

    "[ ex : perfect ] the vertices of the following @xmath80-polytopes in @xmath75 are exact for every @xmath240 : ( 1 ) hypercubes , ( 2 ) ( regular ) cross polytopes , ( 3 ) hypersimplices ( includes simplices ) , ( 4 ) joins of @xmath394-level polytopes , and ( 5 ) stable set polytopes of perfect graphs on @xmath240 vertices .     "the bound on the number of vertices is immediate by corollary  [ cor : perfect ] ( 4 ) and is achieved by @xmath516^d$ ] .    for a polytope @xmath517 with an exact vertex set @xmath1 , define a * face pair * to be an unordered pair @xmath518 of proper faces of @xmath517 such that @xmath519 and @xmath520 and @xmath521 lie in parallel hyperplanes , or equivalently , there exists a linear form @xmath522 such that @xmath523 and @xmath524 .",
    "we will show that if @xmath525 then @xmath517 has at most @xmath526 face pairs and @xmath514 facets .    if @xmath527 , then an exact @xmath1 consists of two distinct points and @xmath517 has two facets and one face pair as desired .",
    "assume the result holds for @xmath528-polytopes with exact vertex sets and consider a @xmath25-polytope @xmath517 with exact vertex set @xmath1 .",
    "let @xmath479 be a facet of @xmath517 which by theorem [ thm : perfect ] , is in a face pair @xmath529 of @xmath517 .",
    "since exactness does not depend on the affine embedding , we may assume that @xmath517 is full - dimensional and that @xmath479 spans the hyperplane @xmath530 , while @xmath531 lies in @xmath532 .",
    "by corollary [ cor : perfect ] , @xmath479 satisfies the induction hypothesis and so has at most @xmath533 face pairs .",
    "any face pair of @xmath517 besides @xmath529 induces a face pair of @xmath479 by intersection with @xmath479 , and every facet of @xmath517 is in a face pair of @xmath517 since @xmath1 is exact .",
    "the plan is to count how many face pairs of @xmath517 induce the same face pair of @xmath479 and the number of facets they contain .",
    "fix a face pair @xmath518 of @xmath479 , with associated linear form @xmath534 depending only on @xmath535 .",
    "suppose @xmath518 is induced by a face pair of @xmath517 with associated linear form @xmath536 .",
    "since @xmath122 and @xmath534 agree on every vertex of @xmath479 , a facet of @xmath517 , @xmath537 for some constant @xmath538 .    if @xmath539 takes the same value @xmath540 on all of @xmath531 , then @xmath541 which implies that @xmath542 or @xmath543",
    "the two possibilities lead to the face pairs @xmath544 and @xmath545 of @xmath517 .",
    "each such pair contains at most one facet of @xmath517 .",
    "if @xmath539 takes more than one value on the vertices of @xmath531 , then these values must be @xmath540 and @xmath546 for some @xmath540 since @xmath122 takes values @xmath547 and @xmath34 on the vertices of @xmath531 . in that case , @xmath542 , so @xmath122 is unique and we get at most one face pair of @xmath517 inducing @xmath518 .",
    "this pair will contain at most two facets of @xmath517 .",
    "since there are at most @xmath548 face pairs in @xmath479 , they give us at most @xmath549 face pairs and facets of @xmath517 .",
    "since we have not counted @xmath529 as a face pair of @xmath517 , and @xmath479 and @xmath531 as possible facets of @xmath517 , we get the desired result .",
    "the bound on the number of facets is attained by cross - polytopes .",
    "gnter ziegler has pointed out that our proof of theorem  [ thm:2^n facets ] can be refined to yield that @xmath517 ( as used above ) has @xmath526 face pairs if and only if it is a simplex and @xmath514 facets if and only if it is a regular cross - polytope .",
    "recall that problem  [ prob : lovasz ] was inspired by perfect graphs .",
    "theorem  [ thm : perfect ] adds to the characterizations of a perfect graph ( c.f .",
    "theorem  [ thm : knownforperfectgraphs ] ) as follows .",
    "[ cor : perfectgraph ] for a graph @xmath336 , let @xmath395 denote the set of characteristic vectors of stable sets in @xmath336 .",
    "then the following are equivalent .    1 .",
    "the graph @xmath336 is perfect .",
    "2 .   the stable set polytope , @xmath348 , is a @xmath394-level polytope .",
    "a polytope @xmath517 in @xmath550 is said to be * down - closed * if for all @xmath551 and @xmath552 such that @xmath553 for @xmath327 , @xmath554 . for a graph @xmath336 , @xmath348 is a down - closed @xmath80-polytope , and @xmath336 is perfect if and only if the vertex set of @xmath348 is exact .",
    "we now prove that all down - closed @xmath80-polytopes with exact vertex sets are stable set polytopes of perfect graphs .",
    "[ thm : down - closed perfect ] let @xmath555 be a down - closed @xmath80-polytope and @xmath1 be its set of vertices .",
    "then @xmath1 is exact if and only if all facets of @xmath517 are either defined by non - negativity constraints on the variables or by an inequality of the form @xmath556 for some @xmath557 $ ] .",
    "if @xmath517 is not full - dimensional then since it is down - closed , it must be contained in a coordinate hyperplane @xmath558 and the arguments below can be repeated in this lower - dimensional space .",
    "so we may assume that @xmath517 is @xmath240-dimensional .",
    "then since @xmath517 is down - closed , @xmath1 contains @xmath559 .    if all facets of @xmath517 are of the stated form , using that @xmath560 , it is straight forward to check that @xmath1 is exact . now assume that @xmath1 is exact and @xmath561 is a facet inequality of @xmath517 that is not a non - negativity constraint",

    "therefore , for all @xmath409 , @xmath568 equals @xmath547 or @xmath538 , so @xmath569 is either @xmath547 or @xmath538 . dividing through by @xmath538",
    ", we get that the facet inequality @xmath561 is of the form @xmath570 for some @xmath557 $ ] .",
    "[ cor : down - closed perfect ] let @xmath571 be a full - dimensional down - closed @xmath80-polytope and @xmath1 be its vertex set .",
    "then @xmath1 is exact if and only if @xmath517 is the stable set polytope of a perfect graph .    by corollary  [ cor : perfectgraph ]",

    "therefore , @xmath85 is a stable set of @xmath336 and @xmath582 .",
    "if @xmath576 $ ] is a stable set of @xmath336 then , by construction , for every @xmath5 indexing a facet inequality of @xmath517 , @xmath583 lies on either @xmath584 or @xmath585 .",

    "* theorem  9.2.4 iii . ) .",
    "in this last section we describe @xmath82 for an arbitrary ( not necessarily real radical or zero - dimensional ) ideal @xmath588 $ ] .",
    "the main structural result is theorem  [ thm : intersection ] which allows the construction of non - trivial high - dimensional @xmath58-exact ideals as in example  [ ex : infinite perfect set ] .    in this study , the _ convex quadrics _ in @xmath6 $ ] play a particularly important role .",
    "these are precisely the polynomials of degree two that can be written as @xmath589 , where @xmath590 is an @xmath591 positive semidefinite matrix , @xmath592 and @xmath593 .",
    "note that every sum of squares of linear polynomials in @xmath6 $ ] is a convex quadric .",
    "if @xmath594 , there exists a degree one polynomial @xmath11 that is strictly positive on @xmath82 , hence @xmath34-sos modulo @xmath5 .",
    "then @xmath596 mod @xmath5 for some @xmath34-sos @xmath597 and @xmath598 is a convex quadric .",
    "conversely , suppose @xmath599 with @xmath600 .",
    "then for any @xmath601 , @xmath602 therefore , since @xmath603 is a sum of squares of linear polynomials , the linear polynomial @xmath604 is @xmath34-sos mod @xmath5 and @xmath82 must satisfy it . since",

    "[ ex : infinite perfect set ] theorem  [ thm : intersection ] shows that some non - principal ideals such as @xmath650 $ ] are @xmath58-exact .",
    "since @xmath651 , fixing the third coordinate we get the four points @xmath652 where @xmath653 which implies that @xmath654 it is easy to see that the right hand side is equal to @xmath655 which is exactly @xmath656 and so contains @xmath82 which contains @xmath37 .",

    "this kind of reasoning allows us to construct non - trivial examples of @xmath58-exact ideals with high - dimensional varieties .",
    "[ ex : four points ] consider the set @xmath657 .",
    "then the family of all quadratic curves in @xmath77 is @xmath658 \\left ( \\begin{array}{c } x \\\\ y \\end{array } \\right ) -ax -by.\\ ] ] since the case where both @xmath659 and @xmath61 are zero is trivial , we may normalize by setting @xmath660 and get the matrix in the quadratic to be @xmath661\\ ] ] with @xmath662 .",

    "figure  [ fig : thetabody ] shows this intersection .",
    "monique laurent .",
    "sums of squares , moment matrices and optimization over polynomials . in _ emerging applications of algebraic geometry _ ,",
    "volume 149 of _ i m a volumes in mathematics and its applications_. springer , 2009 .",
    "monique laurent and franz rendl .",
    "semidefinite programming and integer programming . in karen aardal ,",
    "george nemhauser , and robert weismantel , editors , _",
    "handbook on discrete optimization _ , pages 393514 .",
    "elsevier b.v . , 2005 .",
    "lszl lovsz .",
    "semidefinite programs and combinatorial optimization . in _ recent advances in algorithms and combinatorics _ , volume  11 of _ cms books math./ouvrages math .",
    "smc _ , pages 137194 .",
    "springer , new york , 2003 .",
    "pablo  a. parrilo . exploiting algebraic structure in sum of squares programs . in d.",
    "henrion and a.  garulli , editors , _ positive polynomials in control _ , volume 312 of _ lecture notes in control and information sciences_. springer , 2005 .",
    "richard  p. stanley .",
    "decompositions of rational convex polytopes . , 6:333342 , 1980 .",
    "combinatorial mathematics , optimal designs and their applications ( proc",
    "combin . math . and optimal design , colorado state univ . , fort collins , colo . , 1978 )"
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> inspired by a question of lovsz , we introduce a hierarchy of nested semidefinite relaxations of the convex hull of real solutions to an arbitrary polynomial ideal , called theta bodies of the ideal . </S>",
    "<S> these relaxations generalize lovsz s construction of the theta body of a graph . </S>",
    "<S> we establish a relationship between theta bodies and lasserre s relaxations for real varieties which allows , in many cases , for theta bodies to be expressed as feasible regions of semidefinite programs . </S>",
    "<S> examples from combinatorial optimization are given . </S>",
    "<S> lovsz asked to characterize ideals for which the first theta body equals the closure of the convex hull of its real variety . </S>",
    "<S> we answer this question for vanishing ideals of finite point sets via several equivalent characterizations . </S>",
    "<S> we also give a geometric description of the first theta body for all ideals . </S>"
  ]
}
